abstract_summ: The models parameters are estimated with Bayesian techniques using COVID-19 data for the states of Ohio and Michigan.Results: We found that the impact of public health measures on the prevalence of COVID-19 could be perceived in seemingly real-time by monitoring growth acceleration curves.Results: We found that the impact of public health measures on the prevalence of COVID-19 could be perceived in seemingly real-time by monitoring growth acceleration curves.Although applicable to disease modelling in general, our results emphasize how network science can improve the predictive power of current COVID-19 epidemiological models.Objective: We aimed at developing a simple framework to facilitate the analysis of the growth rate (cases/day) and growth acceleration (cases/day^2) of COVID-19 cases in real-time.
title_summ: Using network science to propose strategies for effectively dealing with pandemics: The COVID-19 exampleCOVID-19 Epidemic in Switzerland: Growth Prediction and Containment Strategy Using Artificial Intelligence and Big DataEstimating the Growth Rate and Doubling Time for Short-Term Prediction and Monitoring Trend During the COVID-19 Pandemic with a SAS MacroGrowth rate and acceleration analysis of the COVID-19 pandemic reveals the effect of public health measures in real timeAn exploratory Integrated Moving Average Time Series Model of the initial outbreak of COVID-19 in six (6) significantly impacted CountriesTransformed time series analysis of first-wave COVID-19: universal similarities found in the Group of Twenty (G20) CountriesMetapopulation network models for understanding, predicting and managing the coronavirus disease COVID-19A Data-Driven Network Model for the Emerging COVID-19 Epidemics in Wuhan, Toronto and ItalyGrowth Rate and Acceleration Analysis of the COVID-19 Pandemic Reveals the Effect of Public Health Measures in Real TimeNaive Forecast for COVID-19 in Utah Based on the South Korea and Italy Models-the Fluctuation between Two ExtremesAssessing functional propagation patterns in COVID-19A data-driven network model for the emerging COVID-19 epidemics in Wuhan, Toronto and Italy
title_abstract_phrases: The models parameters are estimated with Bayesian techniques using COVID-19 data for the states of Ohio and Michigan.Although applicable to disease modelling in general, our results emphasize how network science can improve the predictive power of current COVID-19 epidemiological models.We provide commented source code for all our analyses so that they can easily be integrated into current and future epidemiological models.Objective: We aimed at developing a simple framework to facilitate the analysis of the growth rate (cases/day) and growth acceleration (cases/day^2) of COVID-19 cases in real-time.Objective: We aimed at developing a simple framework to facilitate the analysis of the growth rate (cases/day) and growth acceleration (cases/day(2)) of COVID-19 cases in real-time.
